author: By Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Trump Allies Seek Pardons From an Emboldened White House
description: The new administration has created a system for awarding clemency that underscores the president’s grievances about what he sees as the political weaponization of the justice system.
content: On the morning of Jan. 6, 2021, a top White House official assured a Republican lobbyist that his client’s pardon application would be placed in the pipeline for consideration by President Trump before he left office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Brown
title: Climate Nonprofit Sues E.P.A. Over Billions in Frozen Funds
description: In a lawsuit, Climate United claims the E.P.A. is illegally withholding funds that have become a target of the Trump administration.
content: A multibillion dollar dispute between the Environmental Protection Agency and several nonprofit organizations escalated on Saturday when one group sued the E.P.A. and Citibank, seeking access to grant money that has been frozen under President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King and Jeffery C. Mays
title: For Black Women, Adrienne Adams Is More Than Just Another Candidate
description: The New York City Council speaker, who officially launched her mayoral campaign on Saturday, would be the first woman to lead City Hall.
content: As Adrienne Adams officially kicked off her mayoral campaign on Saturday, she urged potential voters at a rally in Jamaica, Queens, to view her as an alternative to the city’s two most recognizable candidates, Mayor Eric Adams and former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Burdick
title: Science, Politics and Anxiety Mix at Rally Under Lincoln Memorial
description: Thousands of protesters gathered in Washington for Stand Up for Science, a rally in response to President Trump’s federal-funding and job cuts.
content: Shortly before noon on Friday, Dr. Francis Collins, the former director of the National Institutes of Health, stood on the steps below the Lincoln Memorial tuning his acoustic guitar — a “very sweet” Huss & Dalton, he said, with a double-helix of DNA winding down the neck in pearl inlay. The nation’s anxious scientists could use a song.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: ‘You Can’t Pin Him Down’: Trump’s Contradictions Are His Ultimate Cover
description: President Trump’s shifting positions and outright lies have presented the American public with dueling narratives at every turn.
content: What does President Trump really believe?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Connections Companion No. 637
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, March 9, 2025.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Barker
title: Russian Strikes Kill 20 in Eastern Ukraine as U.S. Reduces Its Support
description: The bombardment came after Washington’s decision to suspend intelligence sharing and hit a region critical for Ukrainian logistics and support.
content: Russian strikes killed 20 people in the war-torn eastern Ukrainian region of Donetsk on Friday night, a sign that Moscow is stepping up bombardments of cities critical for Ukrainian logistics and support and taking advantage of Washington’s decision to pause military aid and intelligence sharing with Kyiv.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 8, 2025
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, March 8, 2025.
content: An article on Page 22 this weekend about the film director Bong Joon Ho misstated the number of feature films Bong Joon Ho has made. “Mickey 17” is his eighth, not his seventh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders and Michael Levenson
title: What Is Hantavirus, the Rare Disease That Killed Betsy Arakawa?
description: Ms. Arakawa, the wife of the actor Gene Hackman, died from the effects of a disease often caused by contact with droppings from infected rodents.
content: Betsy Arakawa, the wife of Gene Hackman, died from the effects of hantavirus, a rare disease often caused by contact with droppings from infected rodents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: Joan Dye Gussow, Pioneer of Eating Locally, Is Dead at 96
description: An indefatigable gardener, she was one of the first nutritionists to emphasize the connections between farming practices and consumers’ health.
content: Joan Dye Gussow, a nutritionist and educator who was often referred to as the matriarch of the “eat locally, think globally” food movement, died on Friday at her home in Piermont, N.Y., in Rockland County. She was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer and Dana Rubinstein
title: 5 Things to Know About the Rise and Fall of Eric Adams
description: Here are five takeaways from the Magazine’s profile of New York City’s mayor.
content: Mayor Eric Adams won his office four years ago pledging to deliver New Yorkers from chaos and calamity — a former lawman entrusted to tame a proudly unruly city.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 2 Books From Other Shores
description: A memoir of Italy; notes on Canada.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Isabella Kwai
title: At Least 12 Injured in Toronto Pub Shooting
description: The pub, Piper Arms, was hosting its opening night on Friday when three men walked in and “opened fire indiscriminately” before escaping by car, the police said.
content: Three men wearing masks and carrying handguns and an assault rifle entered a pub in Toronto late Friday night and “opened fire indiscriminately,” injuring 12 people, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy A. Ruhling
title: How a Sculptor Spends His Sundays
description: Sergio Furnari doesn’t need an alarm for a day of creating art, eating with his daughter and watching the movies in his mind.
content: Sergio Furnari likes to think big. For the last 25 years, he has made a name for himself creating and displaying his giant works of art in public spaces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Impeached South Korean President Is Released From Jail
description: The move followed a court ruling that the detention of President Yoon Suk Yeol was invalid, but it won’t affect the insurrection and other charges he faces for declaring martial law.
content: Yoon Suk Yeol, the impeached South Korean president who is standing trial on insurrection charges over his decision to impose martial law in December, was released from a detention center on Saturday, a day after a court ruled that his detention was invalid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Travis Diehl
title: A Painter Whose Work Is Never Finished
description: Janiva Ellis questions pat solutions with her fractured spaces and artworks that feel as if they are under construction, including some that actually are.
content: The day before Janiva Ellis’s exhibition opened in Cambridge, Mass., on Jan. 31, most of her paintings weren’t done. Most of them still aren’t. In fact, that’s intentional: The 14 pieces gathered for “Fear Corroded Ape,” on view at the Carpenter Center for the Visual Arts through April 6, had been knocking around her studio in New York, unfinished for years, at least one since 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rhonda Garelick
title: About That Giant Kim Kardashian in Times Square
description: The seamless, poreless, sanitized effigy of a capitalist titan was a startling piece of marketing for Skims.
content: Last week, for a very brief moment, something unusual appeared in the middle of Times Square. It wasn’t a marquee announcing the latest TV celebrity joining a Broadway show, or a billboard featuring a lingerie-clad model. And it wasn’t one of those cartoon mascots — the costumed Disney princesses, cowboys and space creatures — who pose for photos with tourists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Musk Doesn’t Understand Why Government Matters
description: If a business fails, it’s not a big deal. When government services break down, people can die.
content: Elon Musk’s life is a great American success story. Time and again, he has anticipated where the world was headed, helping to create not just new products but new industries. His achievements, from his pioneering role in online payments to the construction of SpaceX’s satellite network to the mass production of electric Teslas, have made him the world’s wealthiest man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Christians Are Pressing Trump to Clear a Path for Israel to Annex the West Bank
description: Some 80 percent of white, evangelical Christians voted for President Trump. Now, some want a policy change that could undermine a future Palestinian state.
content: Evangelical Christian leaders who delivered votes to President Trump are now pressing him to declare that Israel can claim ownership of the West Bank, based on a promise God made to the Jews in the Bible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William J. Broad
title: Atomic Detectives Who Inspect Iran Sites Are Affected by Trump’s Aid Freeze
description: The president’s halt of foreign aid upended two U.S. programs that help the International Atomic Energy Agency find clues about Iran’s drive to build atomic bombs.
content: Starting in late January, President Trump suspended two programs that provide American aid to international nuclear inspectors, potentially undermining his own goal of preventing Iran from developing a nuclear arsenal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing, Mara Hvistendahl and Ana Swanson
title: Trump’s Tariffs Could Help Tesla, by Hurting Its Rivals More
description: The electric car company led by Elon Musk builds all the cars it sells in the United States in California and Texas, shielding it from tariffs that could devastate competitors.
content: As President Trump puts new tariffs on goods from China and threatens a trade war with allies like Mexico and Canada, one global company is likely to suffer less than most of its competitors: Tesla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong, Austyn Gaffney and Christopher Flavelle
title: NOAA Said to Be Planning to Shrink Staff by 20 Percent
description: Together with recent firings and resignations, the new cuts could hamper the National Weather Service’s ability to produce lifesaving forecasts, scientists say.
content: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the nation’s premier agency for weather and climate science, has been told by the Trump administration to prepare to lose another 1,000 workers, raising concerns that NOAA’s lifesaving forecasts might be hindered as hurricane and disaster season approaches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Damatac
title: After Self-Deporting From the U.S., My Life Improved
description: My decision to leave the U.S. seemed crazy. I believed then that America is exceptional, the only nation capable of caring for its people.
content: On Jan. 1, 2015, I self-deported from the United States, my home of more than 22 years, to return to the Philippines, where I was born and lived until the age of 9. At takeoff, sorrow overtook the terror I felt at check-in. The T.S.A. agent had scanned my passport — renewed in 2002, devoid of a visa — and waved me through. I froze in place: Where were the ICE agents?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Extra! Extra!
description: Michael Schlossberg’s puzzle might get a little ink on our fingers.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Balk
title: Homeland Security Dept. to End Union Contract With T.S.A. Workers
description: The move could lay the groundwork for the government to fire T.S.A. workers and perhaps even privatize the agency, according to labor experts.
content: The Department of Homeland Security said Friday that it was ending its collective bargaining agreement with workers in the Transportation Security Administration, claiming that the union contract was imperiling the safety of travelers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Farnaz Fassihi and Luke Broadwater
title: Trump Offers to Reopen Nuclear Talks in a Letter to Iran’s Supreme Leader
description: The letter appears to be President Trump’s opening bid to see if a newly vulnerable Iran is willing to negotiate.
content: President Trump said on Friday that he had sent a letter to Iran’s supreme leader offering to reopen negotiations over the country’s fast-advancing nuclear program, but warned that the country would have to choose between curbing its fast-expanding program or losing it in a military attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Newark Police Officer Is Killed and Another Is Injured in Shooting
description: Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey asked people to “please pray” for the officers, who were shot around 6:30 p.m. Friday.
content: One police officer was killed and a second was injured in a shooting in Newark on Friday night, a police officers’ union said in a statement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelle Taft
title: How to Care for a Loved One With Dementia: 5 Expert Tips
description: Gene Hackman was cared for by his wife in his final years. Her unexpected death highlights the essential and challenging job of those who care for Alzheimer’s patients.
content: The details of Gene Hackman’s final days may never be known. But officials in Santa Fe, N.M., said on Friday that it appeared that Mr. Hackman, who had advanced Alzheimer’s as well as heart disease, had spent about a week alone after his wife, who was his caregiver, died at home of a rare viral infection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mimi Dwyer, Jesus Jiménez and Ken Bensinger
title: In the Ashes of Altadena, Rebuilding Is Not an Easy Decision
description: The realities of construction costs and insurance payments after the Eaton fire have set in for residents.
content: The first time Dan Grebow returned to Altadena, Calif., to pick through the rubble of his family’s home, he felt a strong pull to rebuild.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raul A. Reyes
title: My Day With J. Lo
description: Would she swear to tell the truth?
content: I was gazing into J. Lo’s brown eyes. We were inches away from each other, locked in an even gaze, her face tilted up slightly toward mine. I could smell her hair spray. Then the director called, “Cut!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Trump Pulled $400 Million From Columbia. Other Schools Could Be Next.
description: The administration has circulated a list that includes nine other campuses, accusing them of failure to address antisemitism.
content: The Trump Administration’s abrupt withdrawal of $400 million in federal funding from Columbia University cast a pall over at least nine other campuses worried they could be next.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Baumgaertner Nunn and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: C.D.C. Will Investigate Debunked Link Between Vaccines and Autism
description: Dozens of studies have failed to find evidence of a link. The decision to re-examine the question comes as a measles outbreak, driven by low vaccination rates, widens in Texas.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is planning to conduct a large-scale study to re-examine whether there is a connection between vaccines and autism, federal officials said Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Trump Seeks to Bar Student Loan Relief to Workers Aiding Migrants and Trans Kids
description: The president signed an order that would deny loan forgiveness to workers for groups engaged in “substantial illegal activities,” which it indicated included things like diversity initiatives.
content: President Trump signed an executive order instructing administration officials to alter a student loan forgiveness program for public servants to exclude nonprofit organizations that engage in activities that have what he called a “substantial illegal purpose.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Scammers Stole Their Savings, and Then the Tax Bill Arrived
description: The victims pulled money out of their retirement accounts. The withdrawals had inflated their taxable income, even though the funds quickly disappeared.
content: They were conned by skilled online criminals into draining their retirement savings. After the shock, shame and grief that followed, the victims were often left with something else: an enormous income tax bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey and Photographs by Miranda Barnes
title: If You Have to Ask About This Harlem Dinner Party, You’re Not Invited
description: Members-only clubs and private restaurants have become powerhouses for socializing and networking. But there are some spaces you can’t buy your way into.
content: The lobby lacks the swirly marble flooring and chandeliers of finer residential buildings. The long hallways are almost dingy. But behind one of the apartment doors on a recent night, the mood was anything but dull.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Julia Jacobs and Richard Fausset
title: A Haunting Coda: The 7 Days Gene Hackman’s Wife Could No Longer Care for Him
description: The exact details may never be known, but Mr. Hackman, 95 with advanced Alzheimer’s, was alone for about a week after his wife and sole caregiver died.
content: Before Gene Hackman faded from public view in his adopted hometown of Santa Fe, N.M., the locals would see the aging movie star on the golf course or in his truck or walking his beloved dogs in the enchanted western city, amid the juniper and pinyon pine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Twin Test Flight Explosions Show SpaceX Is No Longer Defying Gravity
description: Consecutive losses of the Starship rocket suggest that the company’s engineers are not as infallible as its fans may think.
content: For SpaceX, 2025 should have been the best year yet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Bensinger and Soumya Karlamangla
title: They Can Still Make Art and Music After Fleeing the L.A. Fires
description: Two evacuees took items with them that allowed them to play songs and paint after losing their homes.
content: We asked those who lost their homes in the Palisades and Eaton fires to tell us about what they took — what objects or pets — as they evacuated. Weeks after the fires, those things that survived now hold a new meaning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Frank Saucier, Slugger Sidelined by a Publicity Stunt, Dies at 98
description: He had just recently joined the St. Louis Browns when he was replaced in the lineup by Eddie Gaedel, a 3-foot-7 circus performer, in a game in 1951.
content: Frank Saucier won batting titles in three minor leagues and seemed destined for an outstanding career as a major league outfielder when he joined the St. Louis Browns in 1951. But a lingering shoulder injury and service in the Navy during the Korean War limited him to 18 major league appearances over three seasons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patti Davis
title: My Father Spoke to Me Only Once About Why He Led This Nation
description: He told me once, in the Lincoln Bedroom.
content: My father spoke only once to me about why he wanted to be president of the United States. It was the night of his inauguration in 1981. I had been assigned to one of the inaugural balls and was supposed to wait there for my parents to arrive. After sitting onstage, on a metal folding chair with a crowd of people staring up at me for what felt like an hour, I broke the rules and left. Lying awake in the Lincoln Bedroom, I hoped Lincoln’s ghost would visit me, as he has been said to have visited others in the White House living quarters. I had some serious questions for him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Randall Park on the Kendrick Lamar Track He Loves to Drive to in L.A.
description: The actor isn’t sure he’d make a great F.B.I. agent, though he’s playing one again in the new TV series “The Residence.”
content: When Randall Park was first approached about playing an F.B.I. agent in Netflix’s new murder mystery series, “The Residence,” his first thought was: Another one?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: Who to Blame When the Elevators Don’t Work
description: In New York City, landlords are required to have an active contract with an approved elevator company, and to make needed repairs immediately.
content: Q: We live in a nice multistory rental building on the Upper West Side. Despite the very high rent, only one out of three passenger elevators is working, which has been the case for many weeks. One elevator will be out of service for six months, and there’s no word on when the second elevator will be back in service. There are constantly long wait times, and management is uncommunicative. Do we have any legal recourse in terms of withholding a portion of the rent to reflect this decrease in service?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Gwen McCrae, 81, Dies; Singer Helped Open the Dance Floor to Disco
description: Originally a gospel singer, she went on to meld soulful melodies with dance-floor-friendly grooves on songs like the 1975 Top 10 hit “Rockin’ Chair.”
content: Gwen McCrae, whose gospel-infused R&B hits of the early 1970s like “Lead Me On” and “Rockin’ Chair” featured bouncing, dance-floor-friendly grooves that helped open the door to disco, died on Feb. 21 in Miami. She was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Harold Goldberg
title: Raised in a Civil War, He Makes Games to Bring People Together
description: Josef Fares, whose family fled Lebanon for Sweden in the 1980s, began his career as a filmmaker before pouring his creative energy into cooperative video games.
content: Within a modern but nondescript building a few hundred feet from Stockholm’s pretty Riddarfjarden Bay, a frosted glass wall in Josef Fares’s office displays etched characters from It Takes Two, his video game studio’s “Toy Story”-esque cooperative adventure about an adult couple’s broken relationship. Near his desk, in a lighted case, sits a pair of Muhammad Ali’s boxing gloves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Says It’s Building a Nuclear-Powered Submarine
description: The announcement came amid fears that Pyongyang may be receiving crucial military technology from Russia in return for sending troops and weapons for its war against Ukraine.
content: North Korea said on Saturday that it was building its first nuclear-powered submarine to enhance its nuclear weapons abilities, and the state news media showed the nation’s leader, Kim Jong-un, inspecting part of what appeared to be a new submarine larger than any owned by the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood and Lisa Lerer
title: Elon Musk Is Making Republicans Sweat and Giving Democrats a New Target
description: His unusual governing arrangement with President Trump is opening Republicans up to being yoked politically to Mr. Musk, who polls show is broadly unpopular.
content: He held court in the Oval Office in a T-shirt and blazer with a child clinging to his shoulders. He takes private meetings on Capitol Hill, offering his phone number for senators to voice their complaints, as if they are his constituents. And last month, he brandished a chain saw as he promised to cut spending, to rapturous cheers from conservative activists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Lady Gaga’s Latest Experiment? Happiness.
description: The pop superstar reflects on her struggles with mental health, the pressures of the music industry and why she’s returned to the sound that made her famous.
content: Over the course of her long career, Lady Gaga has proved herself to be one of music’s great shape-shifters. She has gone from the dance pop of her earliest albums, like “The Fame” (2008), to the rockier “Born This Way” (2011), to country-inflected sounds on “Joanne” (2016), to singing American Songbook standards alongside her friend Tony Bennett. Despite surely making her record label nervous a few times, the mercurial nature of Lady Gaga’s gift has come at no discernible cost to her career. She is one of only three solo artists — Michael and Janet Jackson being the others — to have hit No. 1 on the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart multiple times across three different decades. She has also earned 14 Grammy Awards, including one earlier this year for her duet with Bruno Mars, “Die With a Smile.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, William K. Rashbaum and Michael Rothfeld
title: Justice Department Accuses Adams Prosecutors of Politicking and Hypocrisy
description: In a court filing, two top officials released prosecutors’ internal messages in a further attempt to discredit the case against the mayor of New York.
content: Top Justice Department officials issued an extraordinary attack on Friday on the Manhattan prosecutors who brought the federal corruption case against Mayor Eric Adams of New York, releasing a selection of their internal messages in a further attempt to discredit the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: A Europe in Emotional Shock Grapples With a New Era
description: It remains to be seen how far President Trump’s embrace of Russia and abandonment of traditional allies will go. But “the West” may be gone.
content: For decades a core objective of the Soviet Union was to “decouple” the United States from Europe. Decoupling, as it was called, would break the Western alliance that kept Soviet tanks from rolling across the Prussian plains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Took for a Ride
description: Joe Deeney’s crowd-pleasing puzzle reaches great heights.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is a really beautiful grid from Joe Deeney, a steady contributor to the New York Times Crossword since 2017. It has actually been a couple of years since his last themeless puzzle, and there are some of his Saturday puzzles in the archives (here and here, for starters) with similarly pleasing geometry, if you haven’t solved them yet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer, Dana Rubinstein and Ashley Gilbertson
title: How Eric Adams Lost New York
description: He promised law and order. Instead, his scandal-ridden mayoralty became a symbol — and engine — of the city’s chaos.
content: Mayor Eric Adams was milling around a Manhattan ballroom, tuxedoed and small-talking, on a Thursday night a few weeks before the 2024 election. Donald J. Trump made the first move.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Holmes
title: Help, I’m Marrying My Co-Worker and No One at Work Knows!
description: When is it too late to reveal that you’re deep into an office romance?
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon J. Levien
title: An Oregon Family Vanished in 1958. Their Car May Have Been Found in a River.
description: The case of the Martin family’s disappearance has bewildered local residents and investigators for more than six decades — until Friday.
content: On Dec. 7, 1958, Ken and Barbara Martin of Portland, Ore., took their three daughters on a family trip through the mountains en route to collect Christmas greenery. They stopped at a gas station near Cascade Locks, Ore., on the banks of the Columbia River, but were never heard from again.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Reading Two Chapters of ‘The Great Gatsby’ Is Not Enough
description: Responses to an Opinion guest essay by Tim Donahue about reading and learning.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hugh Ryan
title: Think Gender Is Messy? Wait Until You Read These Stories.
description: In “Stag Dance,” Torrey Peters probes the complicated, evolving realities of queerness and trans life.
content: In an 1817 letter to his brothers, the poet John Keats defined the concept of negative capability as “when a man is capable of being in uncertainties, mysteries, doubts, without any irritable reaching after fact and reason.” This is a quintessential trait of a great writer, who must know everything but create characters who know nothing, or only the wrong things, or different things on different pages. In her discomforting new collection, “Stag Dance,” Torrey Peters excels at this particular kind of unknowing. Hopscotching through genres and decades, Peters, across three short stories and a novella, summons up characters whose ideas about sex, gender and sexuality exist beyond (or before, or to the side of) our current orthodoxies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: There Is One Tried and True Way to Keep Birthrates Falling
description: Shaming child-free people doesn’t raise the birthrate. In fact, it might depress it.
content: On Thursday, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention released new data on fertility trends from 1990 to 2023, showing that the birthrate declined slightly in 2023 to 1.62 from 1.66 in 2022. The demographer Jennifer Sciubba summarized the statistics in her newsletter, noting that overall, fertility has declined 22 percent since 1990 in the United States but that “the real decline is much more recent, taking a turn around 2007, just before the Great Recession.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean and Saikou Jammeh
title: Africa Received Billions in U.S. Aid. Here’s What It Will Lose.
description: The United States spent decades responding to conflicts and disease in Africa. The continent is now expected to be the hardest hit by the Trump administration’s aid cuts.
content: The United States is cutting almost all its spending on aid. The biggest loser will be Africa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: What You Will Want to Wear Next
description: Sarah Burton says goodbye to the ghost of Audrey Hepburn at Givenchy
content: At least a quarter of an hour before the Givenchy show was to begin, the white-walled salons of the brand’s headquarters on Avenue George V began to fill up with guests. To understand why that is significant, consider the fact that in the skewed reality of fashion, a show is considered to have started on time if it begins half an hour late. But such was the anticipation for the designer Sarah Burton’s first show. The stakes for both her and Givenchy were high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: With Drones and North Korean Troops, Russia Pushes Back Ukraine’s Offensive
description: Russia has retaken about two-thirds of the territory Ukraine seized last summer in the Kursk region of Russia, but at a fearful cost in lives.
content: Russian and North Korean forces have made significant battlefield advances in recent days in the Kursk region of Russia, threatening Ukraine’s supply lines and its hold on a patch of land it hopes to use as a bargaining chip in future negotiations, according to Ukrainian soldiers, Russian military bloggers and military analysts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kiuko Notoya and Mike Ives
title: Japan’s Ski Slopes Have Too Much of a Good Thing: Snow
description: While the country is having a banner ski season, exceptionally heavy snowfall has created challenges for resort workers.
content: Ski resorts in Japan are prized for having some of the deepest, lightest powder around. A winter of exceptionally heavy snow — some areas had more than 12 feet of snowpack this week — should be a skier or snowboarder’s dream.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Why You Should Sign Up for the I.R.S.’s Identity Theft Prevention Tool
description: With employees from the so-called Department of Government Efficiency poking around in agency systems, faith in data security isn’t what it once was. The tool, an identity protection PIN, can help.
content: Here’s a terrible thing that happens: Thieves pretend they’re you, file a tax return in your name very early in the year, claim a fat refund and run away with the money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Why U.S. Conservatives Should Fall in Love With France
description: Turns out Charles de Gaulle was right.
content: There is a certain tension in the way that American conservatism looks at Europe. On the one hand, Donald Trump and his allies insist that European countries need to step up, behave like serious world powers, and take on much more military responsibility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,359
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, March 9, 2025.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius and Claire Fahy
title: Long Island Wildfire Is Under Control, Officials Say
description: The last of four blazes that began in Suffolk County on Saturday has been put out, but Long Island and the Hudson Valley still faced a high fire risk on Sunday, officials said.
content: The last of the wind-driven wildfires that had stretched hundreds of acres across eastern Long Island, prompting the New York governor to declare a state of emergency, was extinguished by Sunday morning, according to local and state officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: D’Wayne Wiggins, 64, Dies; One Third of R&B Group Tony! Toni! Toné!
description: As a paragon of the New Jack Swing sound, the band recorded three platinum albums and a slew of hits, including “Feels Good.”
content: D’Wayne Wiggins, who brought his smooth baritone to millions of fans as a founding member and the lead singer of the R&B trio Tony! Toni! Toné!, which had three platinum albums and a slew of hits in the 1980s and ’90s including “Feels Good” and “The Blues,” died on Friday at his home in Oakland, Calif. He was 64.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: U.S. Judge Finds China Liable for Covid Missteps, Imposes $24 Billion Penalty
description: The judgment was issued in a case brought by the Missouri attorney general. The Chinese government did not respond to the claims in court.
content: A federal judge in Missouri found the Chinese government responsible for covering up the start of the Covid-19 pandemic and hoarding protective equipment in a ruling on Friday. He entered a judgment of more than $24 billion that Missouri officials vowed to enforce by seizing Chinese assets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: A Play About Segregation Tries to ‘Ride a Fine Line’ in Florida
description: A production partly aimed at students that highlights Tampa’s history in the civil rights movement lands at a time when the state is changing what schools teach about race and history.
content: Given the chance, Arthenia Joyner would have ordered a bacon and egg sandwich with a glass of orange juice. Instead, workers inside an F.W. Woolworth store in Tampa, Fla., declared their lunch counter closed to her and other high school students 65 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: Marrying Amid the Pandemic, and Still Going Strong
description: Five years later, four couples who married at the peak of Covid quarantine share how their relationships were shaped and where they are today.
content: The March 21, 2020, wedding of Julie Samuels and Joe Hillyer in Montclair, N.J., ushered in an unparalleled time for the Vows and Mini-Vows columns. Because of the coronavirus pandemic and its crowd-size and social-distancing mandates, couples had to get creative about how to pull off weddings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Remains in Manitoba Landfill Are Identified as Serial Killer’s Victim
description: The decision to search a landfill near Winnipeg had become a political issue in the western Canadian province, largely because the victims were all Indigenous women.
content: The police in Manitoba have identified some of the human remains found in the search of a landfill near Winnipeg last month as those of Morgan Beatrice Harris, one of four Indigenous victims of a serial killer, the authorities said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: The Liberals Choose a Leader in the Shadow of Trump’s Threats
description: Party members will cast their votes on Sunday in a campaign that has been overshadowed by the unsettling signals from Washington.
content: Between the U.S. tariff “psychodrama,” or, per Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s quip, “Thursday,” and the growing evidence that President Trump’s threats of Canada’s sovereignty are quite serious, it’s been a stressful time for Canadians who are looking for stability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Robert G. Clark, 96, Dies; Broke Race Barrier in Mississippi Statehouse
description: In 1968, he became the first Black person to serve in the Legislature since Reconstruction. Shunned by colleagues at first, he became a political force in the state.
content: Robert G. Clark Jr., who became the first Black person to sit in the Mississippi State Legislature since Reconstruction and who endured insults and ostracism before becoming a force in state politics, died on Tuesday at his home in Ebenezer, Miss. He was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Alfred, No Longer a Cyclone, Makes Landfall in Australia
description: One man died in floodwaters, the authorities said, and over 330,000 customers were without power in South East Queensland.
content: One person was dead and hundreds of thousands of customers were without power in eastern Australia as the weakened storm formerly known as Tropical Cyclone Alfred made landfall north of Brisbane late Saturday. Communities were at risk of major flooding, and officials warned that the storm could bring heavy rains and dangerous winds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Mazzetti
title: Trump’s Affinity for Putin Grows More Consequential Than Ever
description: President Trump’s admiration for President Vladimir Putin of Russia has been endlessly dissected, but the American leader’s policy shifts since taking office again could have profound effects.
content: In early 2017, American intelligence agencies delivered an unequivocal judgment about why President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia had ordered a sprawling effort to sabotage the recent American presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: How Gorgeous Is This Chicken Curry Laksa?
description: The coconut milk broth is spicy, savory and rich, but not heavy, and based on the curry laksa found at hawker centers in Malaysia and Singapore.
content: Does anyone else find themselves happily tumbling into more project cooking lately? Maybe it’s because I’m clinging to the coziness winter provides. Maybe I’ve watched too many charming, ASMR-adjacent YouTube videos of people calmly assembling wonderful dinners in beautiful locations. Or maybe it’s because, if my hands are busy smashing garlic or deveining shrimp, I can’t doomscroll on my phone. Whatever the reason, I’ve really been enjoying my quality kitchen time as of late.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: The Thing That Could Be Trump’s Undoing
description: Voters may resent egg prices more than damage to America’s democratic norms.
content: If there are Martian scholars examining the United States right now, they might be puzzling over the great Trump paradox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Fraternity Member Charged With Manslaughter in Hazing Death of University Student
description: Investigators say that Caleb Wilson, 20, a student at Southern University in Baton Rouge, La., collapsed after being hit with boxing gloves as part of a pledging ritual for Omega Psi Phi.
content: The police in Baton Rouge, La., on Friday announced the first of a series of expected arrests in the fraternity hazing death of Caleb Wilson, a 20-year-old Southern University student who they said was repeatedly punched with boxing gloves at a warehouse last week and was unresponsive when he was dropped off at an emergency room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grady McGregor
title: Trump Wants to Kill Carried Interest. Wall Street Will Fight to Keep It.
description: President Trump has been trying to eliminate the tax loophole, which benefits Wall Street, but Congressional Republicans may stand in the way.
content: Nearly a month has passed since President Trump last spoke publicly of his desire to kill the carried interest loophole. (Yes, we know, some of you don’t consider it a “loophole.”) And yet the private equity industry, which stands to lose big if the president upends the tax break, is still bracing for a fight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natan Odenheimer, Ronen Bergman and Gabby Sobelman
title: Gaza War Led to Deaths of More Than 3 Dozen Hostages, Officials Say
description: Israel’s leaders promised that their military campaign in Gaza would help save the lives of hostages. At least 41 have died in captivity, some killed by Hamas and others in Israeli airstrikes.
content: Itay Svirsky, 40, was a therapist who loved philosophy. Eden Yerushalmi, 24, was training to become a Pilates instructor. Alex Lobanov, 32, a father of three, never met his youngest child.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan and Graham Dickie
title: For the Actors of ‘Sumo,’ Learning Lines Was Just the Half of It
description: The play’s cast members wrestle, slap and toss one another in ambitiously choreographed fight sequences that took months of training to learn.
content: Two men, barefoot and wearing traditional loincloths around their waists, tussled with each other on a stage transformed to look like a sumo ring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maia Coleman and Mark Bonamo
title: 14-Year-Old Boy Arrested in Connection With Fatal Newark Police Shooting
description: The boy, who has not been named, was charged with murder, attempted murder and possessing illegal weapons. The officer who died early Saturday morning was identified as Detective Joseph Azcona.
content: A 14-year-old boy has been arrested in connection with a shooting on Friday night that killed one Newark police officer and injured another, Essex County officials said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon J. Levien
title: Former Ride-Share Driver Sentenced to 290 Years for Kidnapping a Dozen Women
description: John Pastor-Mendoza, a Lyft driver, falsely posed as the ride that the women had requested and targeted victims who appeared intoxicated, the Denver district attorney said.
content: A Denver judge on Friday sentenced a former ride-share driver to 290 years to life after prosecutors said he abducted a dozen women over four years by falsely posing as the driver they requested.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China Hits Canada With Tariffs in Indirect Riposte to Trump
description: Beijing, which set steep duties on canola, peas and pork, wants Canada and Mexico to resist U.S. pressure to raise tariffs on Chinese goods.
content: China announced tariffs of up to 100 percent on canola, pork and other foods from Canada on Saturday, in retaliation for Canada’s decision last August to collect steep taxes on imports of Chinese electric vehicles, steel and aluminum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: Frigid Weather? Rising Inflation? Restaurants Are Having a Big Winter Anyway.
description: January and February are usually the doldrums for dining, but Americans have been eating out, and spending, with gusto.
content: This winter, Denver has faced record-breaking Arctic blasts — below-zero temperatures, heavy snowfalls and brutal wind chills. But at Barolo Grill, a longtime Italian fixture in the affluent Cherry Creek neighborhood, the mood is warm. The restaurant has just logged its most lucrative January and February since it opened in 1992.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Curtis Sittenfeld Has a Question: ‘Isn’t It So Weird to Be a Person?’
description: The best-selling bard of female anxiety rakes over some middle school memories while visiting the city where she grew up.
content: There really was a woman who photocopied her butt at a workplace in the 1980s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Lightening Up
description: Daylight saving time begins tomorrow, and the days are getting lighter and more expansive. If we want to, we can, too.
content: Daylight is adding up, about three minutes more each day as March progresses, give or take. Tomorrow, we bank a full hour at once: Change your clocks, change your smoke detector batteries, start planning menus around tender lettuces. Spring hasn’t arrived yet, but her plane’s definitely left the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: Hundreds of Civilians Killed by Government Forces in Syria, War Monitors Say
description: More than 1,000 people have been killed in fighting between forces of the new government and remnants of the ousted regime, according to a war monitor, which said about 700 were civilians.
content: Three days of clashes between fighters affiliated with Syria’s new leaders and those loyal to the ousted dictator Bashar al-Assad have left scores of civilians dead, according to two war monitoring groups, who reported on Saturday that many of them had been killed by the government’s forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Sullivan
title: Take a Deep Breath. If You Dare.
description: In “Air-Borne,” his detailed and gripping account of aerobiology, Carl Zimmer uncovers the mysteries filling our lungs.
content: At the start of 2020, a small team of scientists tried and failed to convince public health organizations that Covid-19 was spread through the air we breathe. Why they failed, and how they ultimately won, is the subject of Carl Zimmer’s new book, “Air-Borne.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Sampson
title: Iran’s Leader Rebuffs Trump’s Outreach Over Its Nuclear Program
description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei decried “bullying governments” in an apparent response to a letter the White House sent to Iran earlier in the week.
content: Iran’s supreme leader decried “bullying governments” and bristled on Saturday at the idea of negotiating over the country’s nuclear program with the United States in an apparent response to a letter sent by President Trump earlier in the week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelle Taft and Eric Berger
title: Thousands Gather to Oppose Trump on International Women’s Day
description: About 300 demonstrations were scheduled across the United States. Organizers said that Americans eager to protest considered the occasion an appropriate time to rally.
content: From Boston to Los Angeles, thousands of people rallied on Saturday to protest the presidency of Donald J. Trump, including his handling of the war in Ukraine, his stance on reproductive rights and the firing of federal workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Carl Hulse
title: House Republicans Unveil Spending Bill to Avert Shutdown at Week’s End
description: Democrats decried the measure as a White House power grab, leaving it unclear whether the legislation could pass.
content: House Republicans on Saturday unveiled a measure to fund the government through Sept. 30, boosting spending on the military and daring Democrats to oppose it and risk being blamed for a government shutdown that would begin after midnight Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Sonnet’s Ever-Fixèd Mark Did, Perchance, Move
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, March 8, 2025.
content: “Shakespeare has always been political.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis and Akilah Townsend
title: St. Louis Wants Immigrants. Trump’s Crackdown Could Get in the Way.
description: Shrinking cities have tried to stabilize their populations with foreign-born residents. The strategy was working, until the inauguration.
content: At a high-traffic intersection on the south side of St. Louis, in a former bank building complete with a glassy atrium, it’s time for sewing class — held in Dari, the Afghan variant of Persian.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Trump Administration Sends Politically Charged Survey to Researchers
description: Scientists on overseas projects must say whether they work with communist governments and help combat “Christian persecution.”
content: The Trump administration has asked researchers and organizations whose work is conducted overseas to disclose ties to those regarded as hostile, including “entities associated with communist, socialist or totalitarian parties,” according to a questionnaire obtained by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edmund Lee
title: The Future of News Looks Niche
description: The media entrepreneur Jessica Lessin chats with DealBook about the news landscape and her latest media bet.
content: In 2013, Jessica Lessin, a reporter at The Wall Street Journal, left the paper to start a competing publication, The Information.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: SpaceX Scrubs Launch of 2 NASA Satellite Missions
description: The spacecraft, SPHEREx and PUNCH, had been expected to launch on a SpaceX rocket on Saturday.
content: Two NASA missions will have to wait longer for a launch aboard a single rocket. Both aim to unravel mysteries about the universe — one by peering far from Earth, the other by looking closer to home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anupreeta Das and Gabriela Bhaskar
title: The Hot Place to Be Seen for Young Indians: Book Festivals
description: From beaches to hilltops, young people are driving a boom in literary events as they read more in India’s dozens of native languages.
content: Mizoram, a state in India’s remote northeast that shares boundaries with Bangladesh and Myanmar, has one. Surat, a city best known for its diamonds and textiles, has one. Bengaluru, the country’s tech hub with a touch of hipness, has one. Kolkata, whose residents take their reputation for erudition seriously, has at least three.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard
title: 19 Ways Congressional Tax Action (or Inaction) Could Hit Your Wallet
description: Brackets may change. The standard deduction could fall. And President Trump will probably not remove taxes on Social Security income.
content: At the end of February, the House of Representatives passed a budget calling for up to $4.5 trillion in tax cuts over 10 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Rothfeld
title: Read The Brief That Recommends Dropping The Charges Against Eric Adams, Annotated
description: The amicus brief was written by Paul D. Clement, a noted conservative lawyer, at the behest of Federal District Judge Dale E. Ho.
content: The amicus brief was written by Paul D. Clement, a noted conservative lawyer, at the behest of Federal District Judge Dale E. Ho.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel, Claire Hogan, James Surdam and Whitney Shefte
title: How Trump Has Upended the Presidential Pardon
description: President Trump’s willingness to pardon allies has spawned a brisk market for executive clemency. Kenneth P. Vogel, a Times reporter who investigates money, politics and influence, looks at some of the people who want pardons.
content: President Trump’s willingness to pardon allies has spawned a brisk market for executive clemency. Kenneth P. Vogel, a Times reporter who investigates money, politics and influence, looks at some of the people who want pardons.
source.name: The New York Times
